resource.name: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia
resource.description: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia. Includes the following data fields: Year, Zone, Vaccine Type, # Immunized, # Eligible, % Coverage, 95% CI

domain_metadata.value: Current as of January 25, 2019. - Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (TDAP) is administered in a single dose vaccine. Provincial vaccine coverage target is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Meningococcal Group C Conjugate (Men-C-C) single dose vaccine was delivered. Beginning in 2015-16, the Meningococcal Quadrivalent (Men-C-ACYW) single dose vaccine has been administered. Men-C-ACYW protects againsts illnesses caused from serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 of the bacteria whereas the prior vaccine provided protection against serogroup C.  Provincial coverage target for both variantions of this vaccine is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Human Papillomavirus (HPV) three dose vaccine was delivered to female students. Beginning in 2015-16, the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) two dose vaccine has been administered to both male and female students. The provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 80%.  - Hepatitis B (HPB) is administered in a two dose vaccine. Provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 90%. - 95% CI represents the range of values that you can be 95% certain contains the true mean of the population. - The total for Nova Scotia may not always equal the sum of the four zones as there is immunization data reports occasionally that is not identified to a zone.
2012-13 through 2016-17  based on school year schedule (Sept - Aug)

resource.name: Innovacorp Start-Up Acceleration Initiative Awards
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies. 

This dataset includes data on Innovacorp's major acceleration program awards for Nova Scotia start-ups.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of May 5, 2020. Innovacorp's programs change each year as the needs of Nova Scotia's start-up community evolve.   Some of Innovacorp’s program awards are co-funded by other organizations, such as the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency.  Fiscal year ends in March.

resource.name: Sustainable Transportation Grant Projects Total Annual Amount Awarded by Area
resource.description: One of the action items of the Sustainable Transportation Strategy, was to develop a grant program focused on providing funds to communities for sustainable transportation related projects. The grant program, Nova Scotia Moves was launched in 2012/2013 and went on for 2 fiscal years after that. It was restructured and renamed to Connect2 in 2015/2016. Connect2 currently is still running and in it's fourth round in 2019-2020.

resource.name: Premiers' Forums
resource.description: Each year the Premier participates in a number of Intergovernmental Forums.  These include the Council of the Federation (COF, which is also referred to as “Canada’s Premiers"), the Council of Atlantic Premiers (CAP), and the Maritime Premiers.  There are also bi-lateral meetings between Premiers and issue specific meetings (e.g. the Quebec Summit on Climate Change).

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Continuous Water Quality Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network was established in 2002 to assess water quality in surface waters across the province at five stations (and one discontinued station, St Mary's River).  The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the six monitoring station locations within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same datasets: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The data is measurements collected on an hourly timestep using Hydrolab water quality instruments at five stations: Pockwock Lake (NS01EH053), Shelburne River (NS01ED013), Northeast Margaree River (NS01FB001), Kelley River (NS01DL001) and LaHave River (NS01EF0002). Data for the discontinued St Mary's River (NS01EO001) site is for the 2007 to 2008 time period. The measured water quality parameters are the following: temperature (°C), pH (-), conductivity (µS/cm), dissolved oxygen (mg/L) and turbidity (NTU).  Five of the stations are located on watercourses and are co-located with Water Survey of Canada hydrometric stations. All six stations have quaterly water quality samples collected and submitted for laboratory analysis.

resource.name: Innovacorp Incubation Resident Companies
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies.

Innovacorp manages three incubation facilities which are home to more than two dozen companies employing hundreds of entrepreneurs and skilled professionals. The Technology Innovation Centre (TIC) in Dartmouth targets companies in clean technology and a variety of other knowledge-based sectors, while the Innovacorp Enterprise Centre (IEC) on the Dalhousie University campus in Halifax focuses on companies in the life sciences sectors. Start-Up Yard at COVE (Centre for Ocean Ventures and Entrepreneurship) on the Dartmouth waterfront is for ocean technology ventures.

This dataset includes data on Innovacorp's 2018-2019 resident incubation companies.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of June 5, 2020. Some of Innovacorp’s incubation resident companies take space at the facilities for just a short time (i.e., six-months) as their residency is part of an Innovacorp program (e.g., Start-Up Visa Program, Accelerate Program).

resource.name: Nova Scotia King's County Well Water Nitrate Monitoring Data 1989-2012
resource.description: The well-water Nitrate Monitoring Program was a long-term study that involved annual testing for groundwater nitrate from 1989-2012 at approximately 150 wells in Kings County, NS, which is one of the most intensely farmed areas of the province.

domain_metadata.value: Water sampling was conducted from wells constructed for water supply. Units for all data are in Nitrate-N (mg/L).

resource.name: Nova Scotia Lake Survey Lakes Locations
resource.description:
A shapefile of freshwater water bodies hat have been sampled as part of the Nova Scotia Lake Survey. The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between Nova Scotia Environment (NSE) and Nova Scotia Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the locations of the monitored lakes within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same lake chemistry dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: "The digital product includes polygons for each of the monitored lakes.  Disclaimer The Province of Nova Scotia makes no representations, express or implied, as to the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the information, maps and other data provided through this application.  The mapping is a graphical representation not based on survey and cannot be used for any legal or navigational purpose.  Any conclusions drawn or decisions made, based on an interpretation of the data, are the sole responsibility of the user.  By continuing to use the application, the user agrees to the terms of this disclaimer."

resource.name: Innovacorp Venture Capital Investments
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology. 

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies.

Innovacorp makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund, a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. Venture capital-backed start-ups typically have a greater economic impact than their non-backed peers, demonstrating stronger growth in revenue, employment and assets. Innovacorp, however, is ultimately driven by generating financial returns on its fund, and also seeks to leverage its deals with other venture capital and angel co-investors, attracting new capital and expertise for the region.

resource.name: Native Language Of Nominees
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Nominees must demonstrate proficiency in English or French in order to be eligible for nomination, but they often have a native language that is neither English nor French. This dataset provides the the number of certificates issued annually by the native language of the nominees.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2020. While nominees must be proficient in English or French, they may be accompanied by a spouse or dependents who are not yet proficient in English or French.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Business Inc. Film and Television Production Incentive Fund Activity
resource.description: The Nova Scotia Film & Television Production Incentive Fund provides funding for screen-based content creation. To be eligible, organizations must have a permanent establishment in the province and be engaged primarily in the creation of film/video productions for public viewing.

domain_metadata.value: Approved authorized funding commitments are recorded as activity in the fiscal year in which they were agreed/authorized.  Authorized amounts may not be paid within the same fiscal year (could occur in future years).

resource.name: Nova Scotia 1m DEM Pictou County 2014
resource.description: The Nova Scotia Elevation Dataset, consisting of a Digital Elevation Model (DEM) derived from LiDAR data is available for select 1:2000 scale map sheet windows in Pictou County.   The DEM is a bare earth rasterized elevation model with a one metre cell size.   The area collected is a total of thirty four 1:2000 scale map sheet windows for a total coverage of approximately 95 square kilometres.

resource.name: Native Language of Nominees - Total Number by Language
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Nominees must demonstrate proficiency in English or French in order to be eligible for nomination, but they often have a native language that is neither English nor French. This dataset provides the the number of certificates issued annually by the native language of the nominees.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2018. While nominees must be proficient in English or French, they may be accompanied by a spouse or dependents who are not yet proficient in English or French.

resource.name: Mean Annual Substance-related Fatality Rate per 100,000 Population by Health Zone of Residence
resource.description: Numbers and rates of substance-related fatalities in Nova Scotia, 2009-2017

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of May 31, 2018. Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. 'All manners' category includes deaths where manner was classified as either accident, suicide, or undetermined. (Acute toxicity deaths are not classified as natural in manner of death, and no toxicity deaths were classified as homicide.) Data reflect cause and manner of death recorded on death certificate.  Data includes deaths caused by acute toxicity following administration of exogenous substance(s), including pharmaceutical and nonpharmaceutical drugs and alcohol. Excludes: gases and inhalants, death due to medical consequences of long term substance use, medical assistance in dying, trauma with substances detected but not involved in the mechanism of death. NS totals may be greater than sum of health zones as totals include cases where location of residence was out of province.  Data for substances are not mutually exclusive as some deaths are due to toxicity from multiple substances, which may act synergistically to cause death (and may or may not have reached lethal levels alone). As such, counts of deaths by substance cannot be added together for meaningful sums. See the ‘All substances’ category for overall counts of unique deaths and associated rates. Some health zone data were suppressed due to low numbers.  This dataset includes the following categories for drug type: total – all substances, opioid, benzodiazepine, antidepressant, cocaine. Further categorization and breakdowns of substances may be available in future releases.  See related document 'NSMES acute toxicity deaths June 2018' for electronic application key word search terms applied to immediate cause of death and all antecedent causes of death for each drug type category.

resource.name: Industry Specialization based on Business Locations by Functional Economic Regions
resource.description: The dataset provides information on industry specialization, industry structure and number of business locations for Nova Scotia’s Functional Economic Regions.  The data fields include: Functional Economic Region Name, Month and Year; Category (e.g., Farming); Type (Traded or Local); North American Industry Classification (NAICS) - 6-digits; Location Quotient based on Business Locations; and Employment Size Categories for Business Locations.  Fields may be added to or change over time.
columns_name: North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) Title
Location Quotient based on Business Locations

domain_metadata.value: Industry specialization can be measured using Location Quotients (LQ) that compare the regional share of businesses in an industry with the national share of businesses in the same industry.  An LQ greater than 1 suggests the number of businesses in an industry is more concentrated in the region than it is nationally.  An LQ greater than 2 indicates a very high level of specialization or concentration, 1.25 to 2 indicates a high specialization; an LQ close to 1 (0.75-1.25) indicates an average specialization; and less than 0.75 indicates a low specialization.  An LQ of 0 for a particular industry means that no businesses in that particular industry exists in the region.

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Grab Sample Water Quality Data
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network was established in 2002 to assess water quality in surface waters across the province at six stations.  The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality.

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the five monitoring station locations within the province and an alternative method for downloading the same datasets: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The water quality samples are collected typically four times per year at six sites: Pockwock Lake, St Mary's River, Shelburne River, North East Margaree River, Kelley River and LaHave River. The samples are submitted to the Nova Scotia Environmental Services Laboratory operated by the Nova Scotia Health Authority in Halifax, NS for analysis. Field parameters are measured using a Hydrolab water quality probe. The following are the monitored water quality parameters and applicable measurement units: field temperature (°C), field pH (-), field conductivity (µS/cm), field dissolved oxygen (mg/L), field turbidity (NTU), select metals (µg/L), calcium (mg/L), magnesium (mg/L), hardness as CaCO3 (mg/L), lab conductivity (umho/cm), lab pH (-), lab turbidity (NTU), alkalinity as CaCO3 (mg/L), chloride (mg/L), colour (TCU), silica (mg/L), sulphate (mg/L), total nitrogen (mg/L), nitrate and nitrite as N (mg/L), ammonia as N (mg/L), orthophosphorus as P, (mg/L), total phosphorus (mg/L), total suspended solids (mg/L), total organic carbon (mg/L), chlorophyll a (mg/m3) and pheophytin (µg/L).    Five of the stations are located on watercourses and are co-located with Water Survey of Canada hydrometric stations. All stations except the St Mary's River station are co-located with  automated Hydrolab water quality probes.

resource.name: Unclaimed Estate or Trust Funds Database: Total Remaining Amounts by Year Received
resource.description: Unclaimed Intestate Estate Funds – where individuals die and the heirs are missing and cannot be located. Unclaimed Intestate Estate Funds are transferred to the Minister of Finance and Treasury Board who holds them in trust until they are authorized by Governor in Council or ordered by the courts to release them to rightful heirs or for a legislated time limit of 40 years, whichever is lesser. At the end of 40 years, any unclaimed funds can be transferred to General Revenues.

resource.name: Emergency Services Provider Fund
resource.description:
"The Emergency Services Provider Fund is a program intended to assist emergency first responder organizations in Nova Scotia with the purchase of equipment used directly in response to a fire or emergency situation. The program will provide up to 75 per cent of the total capital cost up to a maximum grant of $20,000. This dataset includes the list of the providers that were approved, the inital project approval amount and the actual amount paid to each applicant based on the finished project.
Funding for this program was last approved in 2018-19 budget."

domain_metadata.value: The actual amounts paid may differ from the approved amount based on the final project totals. If the finished project total is less than the approved project totals , the actual amount paid may be lower. In the instance where the actual amount is zero, the applicant decided not to proceed with their project  and did not receive any funding.

resource.name: NS Correctional Services Expenditures
resource.description: The financial expenditures of Correctional Services is an indicator of the resources required to administer custodial and community-based sentences in the province. This dataset provides financial information such as the gross expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections; the per capita expenditures on Nova Scotia Corrections, which is calculated using the total population in Nova Scotia; and the average daily cost in adult custody in Nova Scotia, which is calculated using the adult offender population in adult facilities. Fluctuations in the cost of Corrections may be driven by a number of factors, including but not limited to: the level of crime, legislative and policy responses to crime, sentencing practices, and administrative changes relating to organizational structure and the delivery of services, as well as changes in salaries and benefits for staff. The source for the financial information is the Nova Scotia Department of Justice, Financial Services Corporate Service Unit (CSU). Population data is sourced from Statistics Canada CANSIM Table 051-0005 - Estimates of population, Canada, provinces and territories.

domain_metadata.value: Corrections in Nova Scotia: Key Indicators URL: http://www.novascotia.ca/just/publications/docs/2015-16_corrections_key_indicator_report.pdf and Nova Scotia Department of Justice Accountability Report URL: http://novascotia.ca/just/publications/

resource.name: Number of People Represented by Nominee Certificates
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. 

This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made and the number of people expected to immigrate to Nova Scotia as a result of nominations in each stream.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2020. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: EHS Nova Scotia Volunteer AED Locations
resource.description: This map displays where Nova Scotians can find AEDs (automatic external defibrillators). This map lists both public AEDs and AEDs for medical first responders (MFR). A more recent map may be viewable on the NSGI site. The map is intended for public awareness, to help plan and prepare for a potential cardiac arrest and to increase the availability of AEDs in our communities. It is not intended to be relied upon for emergency response or ongoing administration of AED programs. Use the dataset entirely at your own risk. The information in the map is provided voluntarily by AED owners. EHS and GeoNova have tried to ensure that the information on the map is accurate, but we don’t guarantee that any AED listed is: • still located at the location shown • available for emergency response • working AEDs shown on the map may not be available for public use outside of the locations shown. To access or use an AED, you might need approval from the owner or their designate. EHS Nova Scotia Volunteer AED locations dataset includes the following data fields: Number of AEDs, Location, Address, AED Type

resource.description:
A shapefile of freshwater water bodies hat have been sampled as part of the Nova Scotia Lake Survey. The Nova Scotia Lake Survey program is a partnership initiative between Nova Scotia Environment (NSE) and Nova Scotia Fisheries and Aquaculture (NSDFA) to inventory lakes throughout the province determining baseline water quality, in support of both sport fisheries and water resource management areas.

resource.name: Native Language of Nominees - Total Number by Language
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Nominees must demonstrate proficiency in English or French in order to be eligible for nomination, but they often have a native language that is neither English nor French. This dataset provides the the number of certificates issued annually by the native language of the nominees.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2018. While nominees must be proficient in English or French, they may be accompanied by a spouse or dependents who are not yet proficient in English or French.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Current Speed and Direction Data
resource.description: Ocean current speed and direction time series data collected in vertical profile at various locations throughout Nova Scotia by the Department of Fisheries and Aquaculture’s Aquaculture Division.

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached [Current Meter Deployment Metadata Tracking Sheet] contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached [Current Meter Deployment Metadata Tracking Sheet].  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment.  Because these data are collected in vertical profile at locations of varying depths and tidal ranges, most data sets will

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Station Locations
resource.description:
A shapefile of the Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network monitoring stations. The network was established in 2002 to assess near real-time water quality in surface waters across the province at five river stations and one lake station. The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality. 

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the six monitoring station locations and an alternative method for downloading the same dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The digital product includes points for each of the six monitoring station locations. The Pockwock Lake, Shelburne River, North East Margaree River, Kelley River and LaHave River stations are co-located with real-time water quality monitoring stations. Quarterly water quality samples are collected and submitted for laboratory analysis at all six stations.  Disclaimer The Province of Nova Scotia makes no representations, express or implied, as to the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the information, maps and other data provided through this application.  The mapping is a graphical representation not based on survey and cannot be used for any legal or navigational purpose.  Any conclusions drawn or decisions made, based on an interpretation of the data, are the sole responsibility of the user.  By continuing to use the application, the user agrees to the terms of this disclaimer.

resource.name: Events East Group Economic Impact
resource.description: This data set provides economic impact from two of Events East Group business groups: Halifax Convention Centre and Scotiabank Centre.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of November 5, 2019. All direct expenditures associated with Halifax Convention Centre are considered incremental. 27 per cent of Scotiabank Centre direct expenditures are incremental. Where there are missing values, the data is not available. With the transition to a new governance structure combined with operating both the World Trade and Convention Centre (WTCC) and the new Halifax Convention Centre during the fiscal year, 2017-18 represents an anomaly for the organization and is not comparable to past operations or indicative of future years. Events East Group began managing all operations of the former Trade Centre Limited (TCL) effective April 1, 2017, however, the financial cutover to Events East was triggered by achievement of substantial completion of the Halifax Convention Centre, which did not take place until March 1, 2018. For this reason, comparatives between Halifax Convention Centre and Convention Centre are not applicable.

resource.name: Nomination Certificates Issued
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who fulfil a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa.   

The maximum number of certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2019. A nomination certificate may represent one or more people. Each nomination certificate issued includes the principal applicant and any family members (spouse and dependents) expected to accompany them to Canada. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Examination Results by year and board - Français 10
resource.description: Provides examination results for Reading (scaled score and performance level) and Writing (performance level for four components of writing) for each year examination has been administered. Consult plans.ednet.ns.ca for more information on the examinations.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of April 25, 2019. Assessments were not administered for 2016-2017 school year. French (CSAP) program students enrolled in Français 10 courses write this examination in January or June. French Immersion students do not write this examination.  For the reading portion, students read different types of texts and answered questions about what they read. Students also completed two writing tasks. Student performance in writing was reported for the four components: Ideas, Organization, Language Use and Conventions. Individual student results were reported in four levels: Level 1 (below the expectation), Level 2 (approaching the expectation), Level 3 (at the expectation) Level 4 (above the expectation). Students also received a scaled score in reading (provincial mean = 500, standard deviation = 100, range 200-800). Nova Scotia teachers worked with the Department of Education and Early Childhood Development to develop this examination and to set the expectation of the examination. The expectation is what students should know and be able to do at the end of the course.

resource.name: Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network Station Locations
resource.description:
A shapefile of the Nova Scotia Automated Surface Water Quality Monitoring Network monitoring stations. The network was established in 2002 to assess near real-time water quality in surface waters across the province at five river stations and one lake station. The results are used to help manage water resources, determine baseline water quality in lakes and watercourses throughout the province, evaluate the impact of human activities on surface water, and assess long term trends in water quality. 

The following weblink connects to a Nova Scotia Environment web map that includes the six monitoring station locations and an alternative method for downloading the same dataset: http://nse.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=7ded7a30bef44f848e8a4fc8672c89bd

domain_metadata.value: The digital product includes points for each of the six monitoring station locations. The Pockwock Lake, Shelburne River, North East Margaree River, Kelley River and LaHave River stations are co-located with real-time water quality monitoring stations. Quarterly water quality samples are collected and submitted for laboratory analysis at all six stations.  Disclaimer The Province of Nova Scotia makes no representations, express or implied, as to the accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the information, maps and other data provided through this application.  The mapping is a graphical representation not based on survey and cannot be used for any legal or navigational purpose.  Any conclusions drawn or decisions made, based on an interpretation of the data, are the sole responsibility of the user.  By continuing to use the application, the user agrees to the terms of this disclaimer.

resource.name: Unclaimed Estate or Trust Funds Database: Total Amount by Probate Court
resource.description: Unclaimed Intestate Estate Funds - where individuals die and the heirs are missing and cannot be located. Unclaimed Intestate Estate Funds are transferred to the Minister of Finance and Treasury Board who holds them in trust until they are authorized by Governor in Council or ordered by the courts to release them to rightful heirs or for a legislated time limit of 40 years, whichever is lesser. At the end of 40 years, any unclaimed funds can be transferred to General Revenues.

resource.name: Karst Risk Map of Nova Scotia
resource.description:
A sinkhole is a natural depression or hole in the Earth's surface which may have various causes. Most natural sinkholes are caused by the chemical dissolution of water-soluble carbonate rocks or gypsum. Sinkholes may vary in size from 1 to 600 m both in diameter and depth. Sinkholes may be formed gradually or by sudden collapse and are found worldwide in ‘karst areas.’ 
Karst areas are not unique to Nova Scotia; in fact, they occur in over a quarter of the earth’s surface. As a result, there are well-established methods for reducing karst risks. These include actions that can be taken both at the planning and construction stage of a project, as well as on-going actions that reduce the risk of future sinkhole formation. 
This dataset was developed to show areas of Nova Scotia where there is a relatively high-medium-low risk of encountering karst and naturally occurring sinkholes caused by soluble bedrock.

domain_metadata.value: All data sets are in six-degree Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) Zone 20 projection using the NAD83 datum.  Reports and Additional Information on Karst and Sinkholes can be found here: https://novascotia.ca/natr/meb/hazard-assessment/sinkholes.asp

West Coordinate: -66.50; East Coordinate: -59.50; North Coordinate: 47.25; South Coordinate: 43.25; G-Poly coordinates: G-Poly Pair (1 of 5) 47.25, -66.50; G-Poly Pair (2 of 5) 47.25, -59.50; G-Poly Pair (3 of 5) 43.25, -59.50; G-Poly Pair (4 of 5) 43.25, -66.50; G-Poly Pair (5 of 5) 47.25, -66.50

resource.name: Innovacorp Investment TVPI Ratio
resource.description:
Innovacorp is Nova Scotia's early stage venture capital organization. It works to find, fund and foster innovative Nova Scotia start-ups that strive to change the world. The goal is to help those start-ups commercialize their technologies and succeed in the global marketplace. Target industries include information technology, life sciences, clean technology and ocean technology.  

Early stage investment is at the core of Innovacorp’s business model. The team also gives entrepreneurs access to world-class incubation facilities, expert advice and other support to help accelerate their companies.

Innovacorp makes equity investments through the Nova Scotia First Fund (NSFF), a venture capital fund backed by the Nova Scotia government. 

NSFF’s objective is to generate a return for Nova Scotia. This is measured by the total value of the investment portfolio (i.e., realized distributions and unrealized changes in value) to the total amount contributed by the Province (Modified TVPI ratio* ). 

*The TVPI ratio typically includes in Paid In capital the amount of management fees paid to the fund manager. NSFF capital funds are 100 per cent used to make investments, and investment management costs are included in Innovacorp’s operating budget. The measure is noted as modified to indicate it is not directly comparable to TVPI statistics.
columns_name: TVPI Ratio (total value to paid-in capital)

resource.name: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia by Year: TDAP (Tetanus, Diphtheria, Pertussis) Vaccine
resource.description: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia. Includes the following data fields: Year, Zone, Vaccine Type, # Immunized, # Eligible, % Coverage, 95% CI

domain_metadata.value: Current as of January 25, 2019. - Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (TDAP) is administered in a single dose vaccine. Provincial vaccine coverage target is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Meningococcal Group C Conjugate (Men-C-C) single dose vaccine was delivered. Beginning in 2015-16, the Meningococcal Quadrivalent (Men-C-ACYW) single dose vaccine has been administered. Men-C-ACYW protects againsts illnesses caused from serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 of the bacteria whereas the prior vaccine provided protection against serogroup C.  Provincial coverage target for both variantions of this vaccine is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Human Papillomavirus (HPV) three dose vaccine was delivered to female students. Beginning in 2015-16, the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) two dose vaccine has been administered to both male and female students. The provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 80%.  - Hepatitis B (HPB) is administered in a two dose vaccine. Provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 90%. - 95% CI represents the range of values that you can be 95% certain contains the true mean of the population. - The total for Nova Scotia may not always equal the sum of the four zones as there is immunization data reports occasionally that is not identified to a zone.
2012-13 through 2016-17  based on school year schedule (Sept - Aug)

domain_metadata.value: This database consists of data from multiple discrete collection events varying widely in instrument make, model, configuration, capability and installation location. These characteristics should be taken into consideration when comparing or otherwise analyzing data from this database. The attached [Current Meter Deployment Metadata Tracking Sheet] contains a summary of deployment specifications related to individual data sets within this database. Each instrument deployment is assigned a unique ID which can be used to filter and separate individual data sets for export from the Open Data Portal.   Data collected using Acoustic Doppler Current Profilers (ADCPs) consist of time-series measurements of ocean current speed and direction collected in vertical profile through the water column and divided into measurement cells of specified size.  These readings are arranged from top to bottom in chronological order and from left to right in order of cell distances from the face of the instrument. For example: the column WaterSpeed_1 contains data collected in the cell nearest to the instrument. The exact location of individual cells within the water column is a function of the altitude of the instrument above the sea floor, the specified size of the individual cells and the blanking distance of the instrument in its current configuration.  These attributes for a given dataset can be found in the attached [Current Meter Deployment Metadata Tracking Sheet].  Each individual row of data (Ensemble) presents speed and direction measurements for each measurement cell that have been averaged from multiple individual measurements (Pings) over a specified time period (Averaging Interval).  The Ensemble Interval (time between averaged measurements), the Averaging Interval and the Number of Pings averaged can vary between data sets depending on the configuration of the instrument used for a given deployment.  Because these data are collected in vertical profile at locations of varying depths and tidal ranges, most data sets will

resource.name: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia by Year: HPV Vaccine
resource.description: School-Based Immunization Coverage in Nova Scotia. Includes the following data fields: Year, Zone, Vaccine Type, # Immunized, # Eligible, % Coverage, 95% CI

domain_metadata.value: Current as of January 25, 2019. - Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis (TDAP) is administered in a single dose vaccine. Provincial vaccine coverage target is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Meningococcal Group C Conjugate (Men-C-C) single dose vaccine was delivered. Beginning in 2015-16, the Meningococcal Quadrivalent (Men-C-ACYW) single dose vaccine has been administered. Men-C-ACYW protects againsts illnesses caused from serogroups A, C, Y, and W-135 of the bacteria whereas the prior vaccine provided protection against serogroup C.  Provincial coverage target for both variantions of this vaccine is ≥ 90%.  - 2014-15 was the final year that Human Papillomavirus (HPV) three dose vaccine was delivered to female students. Beginning in 2015-16, the Human Papillomavirus (HPV) two dose vaccine has been administered to both male and female students. The provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 80%.  - Hepatitis B (HPB) is administered in a two dose vaccine. Provincial coverage target for this vaccine is ≥ 90%. - 95% CI represents the range of values that you can be 95% certain contains the true mean of the population. - The total for Nova Scotia may not always equal the sum of the four zones as there is immunization data reports occasionally that is not identified to a zone.
2012-13 through 2016-17  based on school year schedule (Sept - Aug)

resource.name: Atlantic Quarterly Autumn 2017 Perceptions of Older Adults and Awareness of SHIFT
resource.description: The data set represents the results of commissioned questions in the public opinion survey conducted in November 2017 via Atlantic Quarterly, Corporate Research Associate’s omnibus survey.  These commissioned questions relate to public opinion, attitude and behaviour regarding the Nova Scotia's aging population, role seniors play in economy, support for older Nova Scotians, awareness of programs.  Overall results are provided for each question and results are also broken down by various demographic markers (age, gender, geographic region, education level and household income).

resource.name: Number of People Represented by Nominee Certificates
resource.description:
The Nova Scotia Office of Immigration (NSOI) issues nomination certificates to prospective immigrants who meet a labour market need and who will make a contribution to Nova Scotia’s economy. Nominees then apply to Citizenship and Immigration Canada for a permanent resident visa. 

Certificates are issued in particular streams of the Nominee Program, and each stream has different eligibility criteria. Over time, streams may close as new streams are developed. 

This dataset provides the number of certificates issued annually by the streams under which the nomination was made and the number of people expected to immigrate to Nova Scotia as a result of nominations in each stream.

See https://novascotiaimmigration.com/move-here/ for information on current streams.

The maximum number of nomination certificates that NSOI may issue annually through the Nova Scotia Nominee Program is determined by the federal government.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of February 5, 2019. A nomination by the Province of Nova Scotia does not guarantee that the applicant will become a permanent resident. The federal government has the final decision on who receives permanent residency and is admissible to Canada based on various considerations that include, but are not limited to, health, criminality and security checks.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Grid Shift File
resource.description:
A set of grid shift files that allows GIS users to transform the coordinates of a dataset from Average Terrestrial System 1997 (ATS77) to North American Datum 1983 Epoch (Original) or North American Datum 1983 Epoch 2010 (NAD83 CSRS).

Also provided are ArcGIS transformation configuration files for moving between ATS77 and NAD83 datums.

domain_metadata.value: Product to be used within a Geographic Information System (GIS) for transforming geographic data between datums.

resource.name: Utilization and Payments to the Nova Scotia Dental Surgical Program
resource.description: Utilization and payments to the Nova Scotia Dental Surgical Program. The Nova Scotia Dental Surgical Program provides eligible residents of Nova Scotia coverage for medically necessary oral and maxillofacial surgery when hospital admission is required. Includes the following data fields: Fiscal Year, # of Services Rendered, Amount Paid, Persons Insured, Beneficiaries, # of Services per Insured Person, Paid per Insured Person, # of Services per Beneficiary, Paid per Beneficiary.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of January 8, 2020. Data is based on the date of service.  Excludes any services provided under the IWK Alternate Funded Program.  Persons insured data is based on Statistics Canada population estimates as of July 1st of each year, including Armed Forces and RCMP personnel. Beneficiaries are persons who have received insured services in this program.

resource.name: Utilization and Payments to the IWK Dental Academic Funding Plan
resource.description: Utilization and payments to the IWK Dental Academic Funding Plan.  The IWK Dental Academic Funding Plan provides eligible residents of Nova Scotia coverage for pediatric dentistry services performed at the IWK Health Centre. This includes services provided under the following programs: Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Program, Cleft Palate/Craniofacial Program, Individuals with Special Needs Oral Health Program, and the Exceptional Circumstances Program. Includes the following data fields: Fiscal Year, Amount Paid, Beneficiaries, Services Per Beneficiary, Paid per Beneficiary, Total Services Rendered, Services Rendered - Children’s Oral Health,  Services Rendered – Mentally Challenged,  Services Rendered – Dental Surgery,  Services Rendered – Special Considerations

domain_metadata.value: Data is based on the date of service. Beneficiaries are persons who have received insured services in this program.

resource.name: Youth Programs and Services
resource.description:
Includes  Youth Outreach Programs, A Place to Belong Programs, Big Brothers Big Sisters and Boys and Girls Clubs.

Youth Outreach is a community-based program designed to improve the immediate and long-term social, educational/vocational, economic, and health outcomes for vulnerable youth. Priority is given to youth 16 to 24 years of age who are facing environmental, social, and family conditions that may impact their safety, hinder their personal development, and prevent their transition into adulthood as healthy and productive citizens.

A Place to Belong programming is to support community based youth serving organizations, to provides children and youth age 5 to 16 years with a positive after school and/or evening and weekend experiences that promotes their personal, social and emotional development. 

Big Brothers Big Sisters programming offers a wide range of mentoring opportunities to meet the varied needs of volunteers, children and families. All programs share the same goal: to provide youth with the encouragement and support they need to make positive life choices, achieve more and ultimately, fulfill their potential. BBBS programs partner and collaborate with a broad range of service providers so that children, youth and families have access to a comprehensive continuum of preventative supports and services to meet their holistic needs.
Boys and Girls Clubs programming  provides children and young adults age 0-16 with a safe, supportive place where children and youth can experience new opportunities, overcome barriers, build positive relationships and develop confidence and skills for life. Programming is typically focused on children and youth who are vulnerable and at risk and need safe places to go after school.

resource.name: Referrals, Investigations and Founded Cases by Year - Licensing Services & Protection for Persons in Care
resource.description:
Referrals are the number of reported allegations of abuse against a resident in a licensed DCS facility that are inquired into, but do not necessarily result in an investigation. 
Investigations occur after a thorough inquiry into a referral determines there are reasonable grounds to believe a resident has been abused, or is likely to be abused.
Founded Cases is the number of cases where the investigation determined there were probable grounds abuse occurred.

The Protection for Persons in Care Act is an extra safeguard for patients or residents 16 years of age or older receiving care from Nova Scotia’s hospitals, residential care facilities, nursing homes, homes for the aged or disabled persons under the Homes for Special Care Act."

resource.name: Family Support and Strengthening
resource.description:
Includes Family Resource Centres, Parenting Journey Home Visiting Programs and Men’s Intervention Programs (Domestic Violence Intervention).

Family Resource Centres provide community-based services that support the healthy development and well-being of children and youth by strengthening families and communities. Family Resource Centres provide parent education and learning, programs, advocacy and community linkages to enhance family support, child and youth development and resource attainment for families with children up to 18 years old. 

Parenting Journey Program is a voluntary home visitation program that provides individualized and goal-based support for families of children aged 3-18 years, who are experiencing complex social, emotional, and familial challenges that may impact overall family functioning, parent-child relationships, and the well-being and development of children.

Men’s Intervention Programs (family violence intervention) provide holistic intervention and prevention services and supports for fathers who are or have been or are at risk of being abusive in their intimate relationships.  These services and supports are provided within the larger continuum of services for families affected by family violence.  Family violence may include physical, sexual, verbal, emotional, psychological, social, and financial violence and abuse.

resource.name: Boundaries for Municipal Counties
resource.description: This dataset delineates the municipal boundaries for towns and district, county and regional municipalities, as well the village boundaries for Nova Scotia.

domain_metadata.value: Current as of September 6, 2017. The boundary file was created based on cartographic representation of Towns, District Municipalities, County Municipalities and Regional Municipalities from the Nova Scotia Topographic Database. Villages are based on Community Boundaries as in the Nova Scotia Civic Address File. These are not legal boundaries and should be used for cartographic purposes only.

resource.name: Nova Scotia Suicide Rate by Year
resource.description: Numbers and rates of suicide fatalities in NS by year, sex, and health zone of residence.

domain_metadata.value: Data are current as of July 2, 2019. Data are extracted from a live database environment and are provisional and subject to change. Some case investigations in recent years remain ongoing. NS totals may be greater than sum of zones, as totals include cases from out of province and a small proportion where location of residence is under investigation.  Data include NSMES cases for which manner of death was determined to be suicide and recorded as suicide on the Medical Certificate of Death by the Medical Examiner.   Geocoding of address data has resulted in reclassification of zone of residence for a small number of cases (compared to prior releases of data).
